results.web_description: The script is obvious, covering virtually every issue that might touch the lives of black women, but Dorothy Marcic’s good-natured, low-budget musical is all about the songs. From “Ain’t Nobody’s Business if I Do” to “Single Ladies,” you could do a lot worse (1:30).
results.date_time_description: Saturdays and Sundays

results.web_description: Did the psychiatrist do it? This small-scale murder mystery has been running in New York since 1987 (1:30).
results.date_time_description: continuing

results.web_description: The tear-jerker story of these trailblazing African-American pilots (2:30).
results.date_time_description: Saturdays only

results.web_description: A “Sesame Street” for confused young adults, with R-rated puppets giving lively life lessons amid the human cast. This 2003 musical has traveled from Off Broadway to a Tony-winning Broadway run and back to an Off Broadway house, with its wit and sex intact (2:15).
results.date_time_description: continuing

results.web_description: Try to remember, if you can, this show’s first Off Broadway performance, back in 1960. No? If not — and whether you have or haven’t seen the many incarnations of this classic around the nation, from high schools and colleges, to community theaters and regional productions — there’s still an Off Broadway cast regularly offering “Try to Remember” and the many other songs from this canonical American musical, in which boy meets girl, forever (2:05).
results.date_time_description: continuing

results.web_description: At this hourlong Off Broadway production, it isn’t the names that go up in lights. Founded by Miral Kotb, a dancer and software engineer, the troupe  iLuminate uses wireless programs to light up the bodies of its performers, turning them into glowing silhouettes that perform in total darkness. Using music, dance and virtually no dialogue, the company tells the story of Jacob, an artist whose magic paintbrush, which turns his creations into living beings, is stolen for evil ends. The results tend to favor technology over art, but it’s still fun to watch these young dancers shine.
results.price: $49.99 and $69.99; $26 for rush and student tickets, available at the box office only
results.date_time_description: Fridays and Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2:30 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 and 7 p.m.; Mondays and Wednesdays at 7 p.m.

results.web_description: How do you describe a show whose script changes with every performance? A few reliable statements: Smooching, sword fighting and water spraying will occur. “Aaarr!” will be heard often. And, most important, it will provide more laughs than there are bones in Davy Jones’s locker. So it goes in this hour long family musical, created by Christopher Leidenfrost, in which a pirate crew is cursed by a sea witch and has to perform a Broadway-style spectacle to get its treasure. Young audience members help write the scenes, in the style of the game Mad Libs. (The run is open-ended.)
results.price: $39 to $99; the $39 tickets are available only by calling or visiting the box office
results.date_time_description: Saturdays at 11 a.m.

results.web_description: The latest and most lavish of this city’s immersive theater experiments includes cocktails, a meal and a circus-style floor show, in addition to any number of possible intimate, eroticism-tinged (but PG-13) encounters with the comely young cast members. The show is not for those prone to social anxiety, but it’s full of gaudy spectacle, with a fin-de-Bloomberg-era vibe (2:45).
results.venue_name: Diamond Horseshoe at the Paramount Hotel
results.date_time_description: continuing

results.web_description: More spectacle than story, “iLuminate” offers technology as its most dazzling star. Conceived, produced and directed by Miral Kotb, a former software engineer, the show employs about a dozen talented, indefatigable young actor-dancers, encased in black suits wired with digitally controlled lights. Performing in total darkness to a score combining hip-hop, jazz and classical influences, they portray the tale of an artist whose magic paintbrush is stolen for evil ends. Much of  the action is like a neon comic book, but it does have its magic moments (:55).
results.date_time_description: continuing

results.web_description: This interesting though occasionally long-winded one-man show (written by and starring Tom Dugan) looks at the life of the Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal (1:30).
results.date_time_description: continuing

results.web_description: Big hair, thrashing guitars and inspired humor augment dreams of rock stardom in this jukebox musical, which transferred to Broadway in 2009 with the songs of ’80s acts like Journey, Pat Benatar, Bon Jovi, Starship, REO Speedwagon and Poison (2:25).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 18 (no performances on Thanksgiving, with an added show on Nov. 26)

results.web_description: This 1997 musical by Bill Russell and Henry Krieger about the real-life conjoined twins Daisy and Violet Hilton, who became vaudeville stars in the 1930s, has received a thrilling revival. The rich score, and a newly revised book with contributions from the director, Bill Condon (best known for his film work), establish this adventurous musical as an indispensable ticket for the season. Erin Davie and Emily Padgett are luminous and affecting as the twins united by flesh but separated by their divergent ambitions (2:30).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, with added performances on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.event_name: ‘The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time’
results.web_description: Simon Stephens’s adaptation of Mark Haddon’s best-selling novel, about an autistic boy’s coming-of-age, is one of the most fully immersive works ever to wallop Broadway. Be prepared to have all your emotional and sensory buttons pushed. Marianne Elliott (“War Horse”) directs the excellent cast, led by Alex Sharp, and the dazzling technical team (2:25).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: A shipbuilding town in decline is the setting for this earnest, ambitious musical with a wonderful score by Sting, and a somewhat diffuse book by John Logan (“Red”) and Brian Yorkey (“Next to Normal”). Fine performances  — notably Michael Esper as the wayward son, Rachel Tucker as the love he left behind and Jimmy Nail as the local firebrand — enliven the proceedings, as does the atmospheric production directed by Joe Mantello (2:25).
results.date_time_description: continuing  (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Ayad Akhtar’s tense, turbulent Pulitzer Prize-winner about the clash between Islamic faith and modern culture comes roaring onto Broadway with a superb, mostly new cast under Kimberly Senior’s taut direction. Hari Dhillon gives a coiled, stealthy performance as the Pakistani-born, well-heeled and thoroughly assimilated New Yorker whose assumptions about his identity are shaken when his complacent life comes unraveled. Gretchen Mol is excellent as his artist wife, and Josh Radnor (“How I Met Your Mother”), Karen Pittman and Danny Ashok give fine support (1:25).
results.cross_street: between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue
results.date_time_description: through Feb. 15  (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: A dramatically slapdash but musically vibrant joy ride through the glory days of the Detroit music label founded by Berry Gordy. Mr. Gordy’s book is sketchy and obvious — you want to plug your ears whenever the music stops. But the music is, of course, some of the greatest R&B ever recorded, and the performers mostly electric (2:40).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 18 (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: This new musical from Tom Kitt and Brian Yorkey (“Next to Normal”) is a gleaming drawing board of a show, full of polished surfaces and clearly drawn lines. The shiny-voiced Idina Menzel portrays a conflicted urban planner pondering two different roads her life might have taken. The show feels less like a variation on a theme, than a dogged reiteration of it (2:35).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: John Rando’s take on this merry mating dance of a musical from 1944, about sailors on shore leave, feels as fresh as first sunlight. With airborne choreography by Joshua Bergasse, the production presents a parallel-universe New York where hectic urban life acquires the grace of a storybook ballet. It’s a bustling, jostling cartoon that floats like a swan (2:35).
results.date_time_description: continuing  (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on  Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Rockettes, angels and magi, dancing teddy bears and a 3-D aerial tour in Santa’s sleigh — this show is as much a celebration of the city as of the holidays (1:30).
results.date_time_description: through Dec. 31

results.web_description: It’s back — again. Capitalizing on the popular movie, Claude-Michel Schönberg and Alain Boublil’s musical about the French fellow who steals a loaf of bread and lives to regret it storms Broadway in a new production. Ramin Karimloo, as the long-suffering bread-stealer, and Will Swenson, as his relentless foe, give a sterling performances (2:50).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Dec. 22 and 29)
